div.head:
Embleme 46. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Two Eagles come together, one from the East, the other from the West.

lg.l: Great Jove two Eagles out of Delphi sent
To th'the East and Western parts, for this intent,
That weewehee the weewemidle of the earth might find;
Which there returning, well resolv'dresolved his mind.
But those two Eagles are two stones, which hasthave
One from the East, the other from the West.

div.head: Discourse 46.
div.ab:
Cicero in his weewebooke of the nature of the Gods declares the most ancient-
Apollo to be the weeweSonne of Vulcan, and keeper of Athens: Which opinion,
if it be, as it ought, transferrdtransferred to an Allegory, is indeed most true; because
Vulcan weeweproduceth the weewePhilosophicall Sol, which is Apollo. But it weewehath-
prævayld, that weewehee was weeweborne of Jupiter; and that Latona having two
children in her weewewombe, Apollo and Diana, which weeweshee conceivdconceived of Ju
piter, Juno being jealous sent Python a Serpent of prodigious magni
tude and malice, to persecute and perplex her being great with child.-
The miserable woman after tedious wandringswanderings was at length brought
by a weeweShipp to the Island Ortygia, to her sister Asteries, who therein
reigned: And that Island, being weeweallmost all overflowed with the Sea,
gave place to Latona being in weewetravell, whereupon it was called Delos,-
which before was 11 A: There therefore being in weewelabour, first came forth
Diana, and weeweshee did the office of a midwife to her mother weewelabouring-
to bring forth her brother Apollo; From whence it came to weewepasse-
that women going with Child did in the time of their weewelabour
invoke her deity, and weewecalld her either Lucina or Ilithya, be
cause weeweshee weeweshewd light to infants weeweborne their eyes being opened:
Apollo therefore being weeweborne and weewegrowne up slew Python the tor
menter of his mother with arrows, and weewekilld the Cyclopes because-
they made lightening for Jupiter to destroy his weeweSonne ÆsculapiusEsculapius,
whome Jupiter condemned to hell blasted with lightening, because
hee had restordrestored Hippolytus to life being weewetorne in weewepeices by horses.
Wee have in many places demonstrated these things to be merely
Chymicall: For Latona, Cynthia, Apollo, and Python are requisites of
the art, which have such a relation one to the other, as weewehath been
declared; but these things being divulged in the writings of the most
ancient weewePoetts, as weeweOrphens, Linus, MusæusMusaeus, Homer, Ct. have given the
ignorant occasion to ascribe religion and veneration to Apollo: Here
upon Apollo is in many places of Europe and Asia worshipped,-
and innumerable temples erected to him; And especially at Delphos
hee had a temple to be worshipped by ancient religion, wherein a great
number of statues made of solid gold and silver or great weight-
and artifice was reposited by Kings and Princes, with other most
pretious gifts, which were hidden in sacred places for religion sake
by men of all degrees. Pausanias reports that a brazen Skeleton of
admirable artifice was hung at the top of the temple by Hippocrates.
That famous Tripos was weeweallso consecrated to Apollo by Pelops, at the
time when weewehee weewemarryed Hippodamia the daughter ŒnomausOenomaus King
of Elis, which Tripos Mulciber made, and gave to Pelops: It was
erected in the weewemidle of the temple, in which Pythia sitting
Discourse 46.
receiv'dreceived the inspiration of the DevillDevil gaping with a wide mouth, and then-
prophesyd, and gave responses to those that desirddesired to know the events of things
to come: Delphos was indeed in BœoticaBoeotica seated about the foot of Parnassus.-
Near to the temple was the divining weewefountaine, named Cassiotis, which, if bur
ning torches was brought to it did extinguish them: if they were removed
farre of, they were suddenly kindled, and weewetooke fire; and the water of-
that weewefountaine being weewedranke weeweyeilded the virtue of divining, but not
withstanding the drinkers of that water were made of shorter life. Con
course therefore being made from all parts of Europe and Asia to the-
DelphickeDelphic Oracle, the Poets feignefeign that place, namely Parnassus to be-
in the weewemidle of the earth, and that they proved by an example of Jupi
ter, who had experimented it by sending forth two Eagles: But this thing
not being supported by the reputation of history, it is not derogatory from the
truth, to ascribe it to weeweChymicall matters, especially Apollo being, as weewehath been-
declared, weewealltogether weeweChymicall by weeweoriginall, though the DevillDevil afterwards-
confirmed the superstition of men, and gave weeweprophesyes under that name.
The two Eagles are two stones, whereof one comes from the East, the-
other from the West, which the Philosophers have many weewewayes demonstra
ted. Jupiter sends them forth, as his Ensigne=bearersEnsign=bearers. The Eagle seems in
deed a weewefreind to Apollo or the weeweSunne, in proving her chickens at the weeweSunne,-
which if they cannot endure, weeweShee disownesdisowns them as illegitimate. Its feathers
being weewejoyned with other things are weewesayd not to putrefy, and to weewedevoure
the feathers of other birds, easily admitting gilding weeweallso: By old age, or
sicknessesickness it weewedyes not, but by famine; For the upper weewebeake weewegrowes soeso
crooked that it cannot receive food: Which having cast off it plungethplunges weeweit
selfe three times in a weewefountaine, and soeso is weewesayd to weewereturne to youth.-
Hereupon weewesayth the Psalmist: Your youth shall be renewed as the-
youth of an Eagle: This of all birds is never affected with Lightening:
It weewewarrs with the dragon, which hunts after its eggs for the sake of-
them: All the endowments of whose nature have affoardedafforded the Philo
sophers reason to prædicatepredicate the Eagle in their art, and assimilate the
stone to it, whereof innumerable examples being obvious in their-
books, weewewee will not here alleadgealleged more. . . . . . . . . .
